definition: a white substance with a strong smell, used in medicine, for making plastics and to keep insects away from clothes
a long straight piece of metal with a cam on it joining parts of a machine, especially in a vehicle
saying what you think openly and honestly; not hiding your thoughts
a candid photograph is one that is taken without the person in it knowing that they are being photographed
the fact of being a candidate in an election
a type of soft cotton cloth with a raised pattern of threads, used especially for making bedspreads
a factory where food is put into cans
the practice of eating other people
the fact of eating other animals of the same type
a light narrow boat that you move along in the water with a paddle
a place where food and drink are served in a factory, a school, etc.
a small container used by soldiers, travellers, etc. for carrying water or other liquid
a box containing a set of knives, forks and spoons
a jacket, not worn with matching trousers, often showing the colours or badge of a club, school, team, etc.
perfectly clean and tidy, with no marks or flaws
containing no mistakes or faults
without mistakes or faults
a male chicken that has been castrated (= had part of its sex organs removed) and made fat for eating
a sudden change in attitude or behaviour for no obvious reason
the fact of tending to change your mind suddenly or behave unexpectedly
a small container that has a measured amount of a medicine inside and that dissolves (= becomes part of a liquid) when you swallow it (= make it go down your throat into your stomach)
a small plastic container with a substance or liquid inside
the part of a spacecraft in which people travel and that often separates from the main rocket
a shell or container for seeds or eggs in some plants and animals
the state of being kept as a prisoner or in a space that you cannot escape from
a glass container with a wide neck in which wine or water is served at meals; the amount contained in a carafe
a type of hard, sticky sweet made from butter, sugar and milk; a small piece of this
burnt sugar used for adding colour and taste to food
a light brown colour
a unit for measuring the weight of diamonds and other precious stones, equal to 200 milligrams
a unit for measuring how pure gold is. The purest gold is 24 carats.
a short light rifle
the part of an engine, for example in a car, where petrol and air are mixed together
likely to cause cancer
stiff material like very thick paper, often used for making boxes
a large freshwater fish that is used for food
a person whose job is to receive and pay out money in a bank, shop, hotel, etc.
fine, soft wool made from the long hair of a type of goat, used especially for making expensive clothes
a long piece of clothing, usually black or red, worn by some Christian priests and other people with special duties in a church
a person whose ship has sunk (= who has been shipwrecked) and who has had to swim to a lonely place, usually an island
any of the four main divisions of Hindu society, originally those made according to functions in society
a social class, especially one whose members do not allow others to join it
the system of dividing society into classes based on differences in family origin, rank or wealth
a person who is killed or injured in war or in an accident
a person who suffers or a thing that is destroyed when something else takes place
the part of a hospital where people who need immediate treatment are taken
a long loose piece of clothing, usually with a belt at the waist, worn by men in Arab countries
a woman’s long loose dress with long wide sleeves (= parts covering the arms)
a decorated platform on which the dead body of a famous person is placed before a funeral
a medical condition that affects the lens of the eye so that you gradually lose your sight
a large, steep waterfall
thick liquid (called phlegm) that you have in your nose and throat because, for example, you have a cold
causing many people to suffer
causing a lot of problems for people
a set of questions and answers that are used for teaching people about the beliefs of the Christian religion
a set of fixed questions, answers or instructions
expressed clearly and in a way that shows that you are very sure about what you are saying
a small creature like a worm with legs that develops into a butterfly or moth (= flying insects with large, sometimes brightly coloured, wings). Caterpillars eat the leaves of plants.
a large fish with long stiff hairs, like a cat’s whiskers, around its mouth. There are several types of catfish, most of which are freshwater fish.
a person who pretends to be somebody else, usually somebody who does not really exist, on social media in order to trick somebody into having a relationship online
the relationship between something that happens and the reason for it happening; the principle that nothing can happen without a cause
words that are printed below a picture, cartoon, etc. that explain or describe it
the process of one event causing or producing another event
the relationship between something that happens and the reason for it happening; the principle that nothing can happen without a cause
care that you take in order to avoid danger or mistakes; the fact of not taking any risks
a warning that is given by the police to somebody who has committed a crime that is not too serious
a warning or a piece of advice about a possible danger or risk
to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks

having the belief that some races of people are better than others or having general beliefs about other people based only on their race; showing this through violent or unfair treatment of people of other races
a person who lived in a cave thousands of years ago
a man who is rude or violent, and has old-fashioned ideas
